author: norswap
content:
I'm trying to understand the scheme at https://dankradfeist.de/ethereum/cryptography/2021/06/18/pcs-multiproofs.html
Is it correct to say that the scheme can only be applied with EC curves whose finite field has order `p` such that `p-1 % 256 == 0` ? (where 256 is the project width for Verkle tree)

The reasoning being that the scheme relies on having 256 roots of unity available which is only possible in the above case: if `p - 1` and 256 are not coprime, then the only Nth root of unity (here N = 256) is 1, at least according to https://crypto.stackexchange.com/questions/63614

author: potuz
content: Didn't read the scheme, but the SE post is misleading to say the least. There's a leap from `n` and `q-1` being coprime to `n` divides `q-1`. In general in a finite field of `q` element, there are `gcd(n, q-1)`  n-th roots of unity.  Now  the finite field has order `q = p^k` for `p` prime and `k` some positive integer number. If `p` is not the prime 2, then certainly you will have at least two 256-roots of unity  in F_q since q-1 is even. Your scheme though seems to require that you have 256 distinct roots of unity (I am assuming d=256 in the example you have in mind). And this can only happen indeed if 256 divides q-1.

author: potuz
content: ~~Edit: a browse of the scheme and is not clear to me that you need 256 distinct roots of unity, it seems to use that you have one w which is a 256 root of unity. which is weaker.~~ He does seem to imply that w^0, ... w^{d-1} are distinct, so you really want to have 256 dividing q-1.
